section.title: Configuring email access policy settingsPDM_access_policy_new
section.para: The Access Policy components are the building blocks of an access policy. These components are used based on the scope of the policy and the employed security measures.

itemizedlist.title: For example, an access policy can have one or more of the following components:

listitem.para: Server Name and Domain Name that let you configure the access to the correct server and domain.
Don't allow access if device status is related details that is required for applying the policy to a device.
Other settings specify how many days of past email can be synchronized on a device, and whether or not to use SSL.

section.para: The access policy components are further broken down to specific settings. These settings are the controls that ensure that the scope of the policy is covered and adequate access to IT assets and resources is provided. A collection of similar settings is grouped under one component.
For example, the Email Settings is a group of similar settings that enable an administrator to configure access to the relevant mail server and domain along with other email access related settings.

entry.para: The name of the mail server that you want users to access email from.

note.para: Currently, Symantec Security Cloud supports only exchange server accounts.

entry.para: The email access domain name in the form of example.com.
Currently, Symantec Security Cloud supports only Exchange server accounts.

para.guilabel: Keep emails on the device for

entry.para: To save storage space on your device, you can set the number of past days of emails, which can be synchronized on your device.
For example, Keep emails on the device for = 3 days means that emails from last 3 days can be downloaded and synchronized on your device.

para.guilabel: Don't allow access if device status is

entry.para: As users can enroll their personally owned devices, you may allow users to move company email to personal devices.

You can also specify whether devices can receive company email when they are in a non-secure state. You can make this decision by allowing or restricting email access on Compromised or At Risk devices.
By default, company email access is restricted on Compromised devices, but you can allow email access on both - Compromised and At Risk devices.
The other restriction is whether you want to apply email access policy only on a company owned device or any device.
The option to select SSL encryption.
SSL is used by default, and we recommend that you keep this setting enabled if you want to protect your confidential information such as user names, passwords, and credit card numbers.
